content.title: Non-Invasive Ventilation in ICU
content.summary: Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIV) delivers ventilatory support via mask interface without intubation, with strongest evidence for COPD exacerbation and cardiogenic pulmonary edema, requiring appropriate patient selection and close monitoring for failure.
key_points: Strongest evidence: COPD exacerbation with respiratory acidosis (NNT ~5 to prevent intubation)
Cardiogenic pulmonary edema: CPAP or BiPAP reduces intubation and mortality
De novo hypoxemic respiratory failure: evidence weaker; consider HFNC or early intubation
Contraindicated in: decreased consciousness, hemodynamic instability, inability to protect airway
Monitor for failure signs: worsening ABG, tachypnea, accessory muscle use, mental status changes
Interface selection: oronasal mask most common; full face, total face, helmet as alternatives
content.statement: Non-invasive ventilation is the delivery of mechanical ventilatory support without endotracheal intubation, using a mask interface to provide positive pressure, with strongest evidence supporting its use in acute hypercapnic respiratory failure from COPD exacerbation and cardiogenic pulmonary edema where it reduces intubation rates and mortality.

explanation.intuition: NIV works by providing positive pressure to help breathing without the need for an artificial airway. It offloads the respiratory muscles (the patient doesn't have to work as hard), improves gas exchange, and can often bridge patients through an acute illness to recovery without the risks and complications of intubation.
explanation.key_insight: The key to successful NIV is patient selection. It works best when the underlying problem is reversible within hours to days (COPD exacerbation, flash pulmonary edema) and the patient can cooperate with the interface. Using NIV inappropriately can delay needed intubation and worsen outcomes.
explanation.technical_details: CPAP provides continuous positive airway pressure throughout the respiratory cycle, recruiting alveoli and reducing preload. BiPAP (bilevel positive airway pressure) adds inspiratory pressure support above the expiratory pressure, augmenting tidal volume. Typical starting settings: IPAP 10-12 cm H2O, EPAP 5 cm H2O, titrate for comfort and ABG improvement.

definitions_glossary.non_invasive_ventilation: Mechanical ventilatory support delivered via mask interface without endotracheal tube
definitions_glossary.cpap: Continuous positive airway pressure - single pressure level throughout breath cycle
definitions_glossary.bipap: Bilevel positive airway pressure - higher pressure on inspiration, lower on expiration
definitions_glossary.ipap: Inspiratory positive airway pressure - pressure during inhalation in BiPAP mode
definitions_glossary.epap: Expiratory positive airway pressure - pressure during exhalation; equivalent to PEEP
definitions_glossary.pressure_support: Difference between IPAP and EPAP; provides ventilatory augmentation
definitions_glossary.oronasal_mask: Most common NIV interface covering nose and mouth
definitions_glossary.helmet_interface: Transparent hood covering entire head; reduces leak and skin breakdown
definitions_glossary.patient_ventilator_asynchrony: Mismatch between patient effort and ventilator delivery; common NIV problem
definitions_glossary.niv_failure: Clinical deterioration or lack of improvement requiring escalation to intubation
definitions_glossary.hypercapnic_respiratory_failure: Type 2 failure with elevated CO2; responds well to NIV
definitions_glossary.cardiogenic_pulmonary_edema: Fluid in lungs from heart failure; responds to positive pressure

mechanism_of_benefit.copd_exacerbation: NIV unloads respiratory muscles, reduces work of breathing, improves ventilation and CO2 clearance
mechanism_of_benefit.cardiogenic_edema: Positive pressure reduces preload (decreases venous return) and afterload (helps LV ejection), improves oxygenation through alveolar recruitment

physiologic_effects.respiratory: Increased tidal volume, reduced dead space ventilation, alveolar recruitment
physiologic_effects.cardiovascular: Reduced preload, reduced LV transmural pressure, improved cardiac output in failure

strong_evidence.copd_exacerbation: Hypercapnic respiratory failure with pH <7.35; NNT ~5 to prevent intubation
strong_evidence.cardiogenic_pulmonary_edema: CPAP or BiPAP reduces intubation, mortality; NNT ~8

moderate_evidence.immunocompromised: Avoid intubation complications in immunosuppressed patients

uncertain_evidence.de_novo_hypoxemic_failure: Less clear benefit; HFNC may be preferable; close monitoring essential
uncertain_evidence.ards: Generally prefer intubation for lung-protective ventilation; helmet NIV studied

absolute: Respiratory arrest or need for immediate intubation
Unable to protect airway (excessive secretions, vomiting)
Facial trauma or surgery precluding mask fit

interface_selection.oronasal_mask: Most commonly used; covers nose and mouth
interface_selection.nasal_mask: Less common in acute setting; mouth leak problematic
interface_selection.helmet: Reduces leak and skin breakdown; may improve outcomes in hypoxemia

initial_settings.bipap_typical: IPAP 10-12 cm H2O, EPAP 5 cm H2O; titrate up for comfort and effect

monitoring.early_response: Check ABG at 1-2 hours; improvement in pH/CO2 predicts success
monitoring.clinical_signs: Respiratory rate, accessory muscle use, mental status, patient-ventilator synchrony
monitoring.failure_criteria: Worsening ABG, severe distress, hemodynamic instability, cannot tolerate

complications.interface_related: Skin breakdown, claustrophobia, aerophagia, eye irritation from leak
complications.delayed_intubation: Most important complication - failing to recognize NIV failure

skos.definition: Delivery of positive pressure ventilatory support via mask interface without endotracheal intubation, particularly effective for hypercapnic respiratory failure and cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

icd10_pcs.display: Respiratory ventilation, continuous positive airway pressure

learning_objectives: Identify appropriate candidates for non-invasive ventilation
Compare CPAP and BiPAP mechanisms and applications
Describe initial settings and titration of NIV
Recognize signs of NIV failure requiring intubation
Select appropriate interface for patient needs
clinical_pearls: COPD exacerbation with pH 7.25-7.35 is the sweet spot for NIV - acidemic but not too severe
If ABG doesn't improve within 1-2 hours of NIV, reassess and consider intubation
Flash pulmonary edema responds dramatically to CPAP/BiPAP - positive pressure is the treatment
NIV in de novo hypoxemic failure is controversial - don't delay intubation if failing
Helmet interface may be superior to face mask for hypoxemic failure - ongoing research
Patient cooperation is essential - agitation or inability to tolerate interface predicts failure

board_yield.usmle_step1: Physiology of positive pressure, preload/afterload effects
board_yield.abim_critical_care: Interface selection, synchrony issues, weaning strategies

common_misconceptions: Misconception: NIV works for all respiratory failure. Reality: Strongest evidence is for COPD and cardiogenic edema; hypoxemic failure evidence is weaker
Misconception: NIV can always avoid intubation. Reality: Recognizing failure and timely intubation is critical
Misconception: Higher pressures are always better. Reality: Start low and titrate; high pressures increase leak and discomfort

citations.reference: Rochwerg B, et al. Official ERS/ATS clinical practice guidelines: noninvasive ventilation for acute respiratory failure. Eur Respir J. 2017;50(2):1602426.
